        <a href="/wiki/File:Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Photograph of the Argentine Constitution." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/220px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/330px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg/440px-Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="1880"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Constitucion_Nacional_Interior_Congreso.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Two members of the <a href="/wiki/Regiment_of_Mounted_Grenadiers" class="mw-redirect" title="Regiment of Mounted Grenadiers">Regiment of Mounted Grenadiers</a> guarding the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Argentina" title="Constitution of Argentina">Constitution of the Argentine Nation</a> inside the <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_the_Argentine_National_Congress" title="Palace of the Argentine National Congress">Palace of the Congress</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn" title="Raúl Alfonsín">Raúl Alfonsín</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1983" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 1983">1983 elections</a> campaigning for the prosecution of those responsible for <a href="/wiki/Human_rights" title="Human rights">human rights</a> violations during the <i>Proceso</i>: the <a href="/wiki/Trial_of_the_Juntas" title="Trial of the Juntas">Trial of the Juntas</a> and other martial courts sentenced all the coup's leaders but, under military pressure, he also enacted the <a href="/wiki/Full_Stop_Law" class="mw-redirect" title="Full Stop Law">Full Stop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Due_Obedience" title="Law of Due Obedience">Due Obedience</a> laws,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[111]</a></sup> which halted prosecutions further down the <a href="/wiki/Chain_of_command" class="mw-redirect" title="Chain of command">chain of command</a>. The worsening economic crisis and <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a> reduced his popular support and the Peronist <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Menem" title="Carlos Menem">Carlos Menem</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1989" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 1989">1989 election</a>. Soon after, <a href="/wiki/1989_riots_in_Argentina" title="1989 riots in Argentina">riots forced Alfonsín to an early resignation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011533–49vol._II_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011533–49vol._II-120">[112]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Menem embraced <a href="/wiki/Neo-liberalism" class="mw-redirect" title="Neo-liberalism">neo-liberal</a> policies:<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20066_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20066-121">[113]</a></sup> a <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Currency_Board" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine Currency Board">fixed exchange rate</a>, business <a href="/wiki/Deregulation" title="Deregulation">deregulation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Privatization" title="Privatization">privatizations</a> and dismantling of <a href="/wiki/Protectionism" title="Protectionism">protectionist</a> barriers normalized the economy for a while. He pardoned the officers who had been sentenced during Alfonsín's government. The <a href="/wiki/1994_amendment_of_the_Argentine_Constitution" class="mw-redirect" title="1994 amendment of the Argentine Constitution">1994 Constitutional Amendment</a> allowed Menem to <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1995" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 1995">be elected for a second term</a>. The economy began to decline in 1995, with increasing unemployment and recession;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069-122">[114]</a></sup> led by <a href="/wiki/Fernando_de_la_R%C3%BAa" title="Fernando de la Rúa">Fernando de la Rúa</a>, the UCR returned to the presidency in the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_1999" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 1999">1999 elections</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011551–573vol._II_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011551–573vol._II-123">[115]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>De la Rúa kept Menem's economic plan despite the worsening crisis, which led to growing social discontent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069_122-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin20069-122">[114]</a></sup> A massive <a href="/wiki/Capital_flight" title="Capital flight">capital flight</a> was responded to with a <a href="/wiki/Corralito" title="Corralito">freezing of bank accounts</a>, generating further turmoil. The <a href="/wiki/December_2001_riots_in_Argentina" title="December 2001 riots in Argentina">December 2001 riots</a> forced him to resign.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011575–87vol._II_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011575–87vol._II-124">[116]</a></sup> Congress appointed <a href="/wiki/Eduardo_Duhalde" title="Eduardo Duhalde">Eduardo Duhalde</a> as acting president, who abrogated the fixed exchange rate established by Menem,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200612_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200612-125">[117]</a></sup> causing many Argentines to lose a significant portion of their savings. By the late 2002 the economic crisis began to recede, but the assassination of two <i><a href="/wiki/Piquetero" title="Piquetero">piqueteros</a></i> by the police caused political commotion, prompting Duhalde to move elections forward.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613-126">[118]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner" title="Néstor Kirchner">Néstor Kirchner</a> was <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2003" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 2003">elected as the new president</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011587–95vol._II_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011587–95vol._II-127">[119]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Boosting the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Keynesianism" class="mw-redirect" title="Neo-Keynesianism">neo-Keynesian</a> economic policies<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200613-126">[118]</a></sup> laid by Duhalde, Kirchner ended the economic crisis attaining significant fiscal and trade surpluses, and steep GDP growth.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200616_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200616-128">[120]</a></sup> Under his administration Argentina <a href="/wiki/Argentine_debt_restructuring" title="Argentine debt restructuring">restructured its defaulted debt</a> with an unprecedented discount of about 70% on most bonds, paid off debts with the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200615_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200615-129">[121]</a></sup> purged the military of officers with doubtful human rights records,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200614_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEpsteinPion-Berlin200614-130">[122]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Void_(law)" title="Void (law)">nullified and voided</a> the Full Stop and Due Obedience laws,<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[123]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[F]</a></sup> ruled them as unconstitutional, and resumed legal prosecution of the Juntas' crimes. He did not run for reelection, promoting instead the candidacy of his wife, senator <a href="/wiki/Cristina_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Kirchner" title="Cristina Fernández de Kirchner">Cristina Fernández de Kirchner</a>, who was <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2007" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 2007">elected in 2007</a><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011597–626vol._II_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011597–626vol._II-134">[125]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2011" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 2011">reelected in 2011</a>. Fernández de Kirchner's administration sought a positive foreign policy with good relations with countries with questionable human rights records, including Venezuela, Iran and Cuba; while at the same time relations with the United States and United Kingdom remained heavily strained. </p>
      <p>On 22 November 2015, after a tie in the first round of <a href="/wiki/Argentine_general_election,_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine general election, 2015">presidential elections on 25 October</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauricio_Macri" title="Mauricio Macri">Mauricio Macri</a> won the first <a href="/wiki/Ballotage_in_Argentina" title="Ballotage in Argentina">ballotage</a> in Argentina's history, beating <a href="/wiki/Front_for_Victory" title="Front for Victory">Front for Victory</a> candidate <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Scioli" title="Daniel Scioli">Daniel Scioli</a> and becoming president-elect. Macri was the first democratically elected non <a href="/wiki/Justicialist_Party" title="Justicialist Party">peronist</a> president since 1916 that managed to see his presidency to the end without being overthrown.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[126]</a></sup> He took office on 10 December 2015 and inherited an economy with a high inflation rate and in a poor shape. In April 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Mauricio_Macri" title="Presidency of Mauricio Macri">Macri Government</a> introduced austerity measures intended to tackle <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> and the overblown public deficits.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[127]</a></sup> Though he managed tepid economic recovery, inflation rates remained high. He ran for re-election in 2019 but lost to <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Alberto Fernández">Alberto Fernández</a>, the kirchnerist candidate. </p>
      <p>President Alberto Fernández and Vice President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner took office on December 2019, just months before the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Argentina" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina">Covid-19 pandemic hit Argentina</a> and among accusations of <a href="/wiki/Corruption" title="Corruption">corruption</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Route_of_the_K-Money" title="The Route of the K-Money">misuse of public funds during Nestor and Cristina Fernández de Kirchner's presidencies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Mercopress_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mercopress-138">[129]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Argentina" title="Geography of Argentina">Geography of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Aconcagua_2019.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Mountain tops, with clouds shown." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aconcagua_2019.jpg/220px-Aconcagua_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aconcagua_2019.jpg/330px-Aconcagua_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Aconcagua_2019.jpg/440px-Aconcagua_2019.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4272" data-file-height="2848"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Aconcagua_2019.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Aconcagua" title="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Extremes_of_Altitude" class="mw-redirect" title="Extremes of Altitude">highest mountain</a> outside of Asia, at 6,960.8 metres (22,837&nbsp;ft), and the highest point in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNC-Sigma_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNC-Sigma-139">[130]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With a mainland surface area of 2,780,400&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (1,073,518&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-excl_area_18-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-excl_area-18">[B]</a></sup> Argentina is located in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Cone" title="Southern Cone">southern South America</a>, sharing land borders with Chile across the <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andes</a> to the west;<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[131]</a></sup> Bolivia and Paraguay to the north; Brazil to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and the <a href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_Ocean" class="mw-redirect" title="South Atlantic Ocean">South Atlantic Ocean</a> to the east;<sup id="cite_ref-igngeo_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-141">[132]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Drake_Passage" title="Drake Passage">Drake Passage</a> to the south;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcKinney19936FearnsFearns200531_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcKinney19936FearnsFearns200531-142">[133]</a></sup> for an overall land border length of 9,376&nbsp;km (5,826&nbsp;mi). Its coastal border over the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata" title="Río de la Plata">Río de la Plata</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_Ocean" class="mw-redirect" title="South Atlantic Ocean">South Atlantic Ocean</a> is 5,117&nbsp;km (3,180&nbsp;mi) long.<sup id="cite_ref-igngeo_141-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-141">[132]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina's highest point is <a href="/wiki/Aconcagua" title="Aconcagua">Aconcagua</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mendoza_province" class="mw-redirect" title="Mendoza province">Mendoza province</a> (6,959&nbsp;m (22,831&nbsp;ft) above sea level),<sup id="cite_ref-ignmax_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ignmax-143">[134]</a></sup> also the highest point in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">Western Hemispheres</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYoung200552_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYoung200552-144">[135]</a></sup> The lowest point is <a href="/wiki/Laguna_del_Carb%C3%B3n" title="Laguna del Carbón">Laguna del Carbón</a> in the <i>San Julián Great Depression</i> <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_province,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Santa Cruz province, Argentina">Santa Cruz province</a> (−105&nbsp;m (−344&nbsp;ft) below sea level,<sup id="cite_ref-ignmax_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ignmax-143">[134]</a></sup> also the lowest point in the Southern and Western Hemispheres, and the seventh lowest point on Earth)<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[136]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The northernmost point is at the confluence of the <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Grande_de_San_Juan" title="Río Grande de San Juan">Grande de San Juan</a> and Río Mojinete rivers in <a href="/wiki/Jujuy_province" class="mw-redirect" title="Jujuy province">Jujuy province</a>; the southernmost is <a href="/wiki/Cape_San_P%C3%ADo" title="Cape San Pío">Cape San Pío</a> in <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego_province,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Tierra del Fuego province, Argentina">Tierra del Fuego province</a>; the easternmost is northeast of <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_de_Irigoyen,_Misiones" title="Bernardo de Irigoyen, Misiones">Bernardo de Irigoyen, Misiones</a> and the westernmost is within <a href="/wiki/Los_Glaciares_National_Park" title="Los Glaciares National Park">Los Glaciares National Park</a> in Santa Cruz province.<sup id="cite_ref-igngeo_141-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-141">[132]</a></sup> The maximum north–south distance is 3,694&nbsp;km (2,295&nbsp;mi), while the maximum east–west one is 1,423&nbsp;km (884&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-igngeo_141-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-igngeo-141">[132]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Some of the major rivers are the <a href="/wiki/Paran%C3%A1_River" title="Paraná River">Paraná</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_River" title="Uruguay River">Uruguay</a>—which join to form the Río de la Plata, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay_River" title="Paraguay River">Paraguay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salado_River,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Salado River, Argentina">Salado</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Negro_River,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Río Negro River, Argentina">Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Santa_Cruz_River,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Santa Cruz River, Argentina">Santa Cruz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pilcomayo_River" title="Pilcomayo River">Pilcomayo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bermejo_River" title="Bermejo River">Bermejo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colorado_River,_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Colorado River, Argentina">Colorado</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20065,_7–8,_51,_175_146-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20065,_7–8,_51,_175-146">[137]</a></sup> These rivers are discharged into the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Sea" title="Argentine Sea">Argentine Sea</a>, the shallow area of the Atlantic Ocean over the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Shelf" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine Shelf">Argentine Shelf</a>, an unusually wide <a href="/wiki/Continental_platform" class="mw-redirect" title="Continental platform">continental platform</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20068_147-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford20068-147">[138]</a></sup> Its waters are influenced by two major ocean currents: the warm <a href="/wiki/Brazil_Current" title="Brazil Current">Brazil Current</a> and the cold <a href="/wiki/Falklands_Current" class="mw-redirect" title="Falklands Current">Falklands Current</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200618_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCloskeyBurford200618-148">[139]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Argentina" title="Environment of Argentina">Environment of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;max-width:312px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:146px;max-width:146px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:105px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg/144px-Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg" decoding="async" width="144" height="111" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg/216px-Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg/288px-Dogo_argentino_recentre.jpg 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="370"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:162px;max-width:162px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:105px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Panthera_onca.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Panthera_onca.jpg/160px-Panthera_onca.jpg" decoding="async" width="160" height="107" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Panthera_onca.jpg/240px-Panthera_onca.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Panthera_onca.jpg/320px-Panthera_onca.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1190" data-file-height="798"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:159px;max-width:159px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:98px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg/157px-Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg" decoding="async" width="157" height="105" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg/236px-Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg/314px-Condor_des_andes_immature.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="2304"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:98px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg/147px-Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="98" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg/221px-Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg/294px-Halbinsel_Valdes_Pinguine.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="684"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Left-to-right: an <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Dogo" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine Dogo">Argentine Dogo</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">Jaguar</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Andean_condor" title="Andean condor">Andean condor</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magellanic_penguin" title="Magellanic penguin">Magellanic penguins</a>.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentina is one of the most <a href="/wiki/Biodiverse" class="mw-redirect" title="Biodiverse">biodiverse</a> countries in the world<sup id="cite_ref-cbd_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-149">[140]</a></sup> hosting one of the greatest <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a> varieties in the world: 15 continental zones, 2 marine zones, and the Antarctic region are all represented in its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-cbd_149-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-149">[140]</a></sup> This huge ecosystem variety has led to a biological diversity that is among the world's largest:<sup id="cite_ref-cbd_149-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cbd-149">[140]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wcmc_150-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wcmc-150">[141]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>9,372 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Vascular_plant" title="Vascular plant">vascular plant</a> species (ranked 24th)<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[G]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>1,038 cataloged bird species (ranked 14th)<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[H]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>375 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammal</a> species (ranked 12th)<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[I]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>338 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptilian</a> species (ranked 16th)</li> 
       <li>162 cataloged <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species (ranked 19th)</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>The original pampa had virtually no trees; some imported species like the <a href="/wiki/Platanus_occidentalis" title="Platanus occidentalis">American sycamore</a> or <a href="/wiki/Eucalyptus" title="Eucalyptus">eucalyptus</a> are present along roads or in towns and country estates (<i>estancias</i>). The only tree-like plant native to the pampa is the evergreen <a href="/wiki/Omb%C3%BA" class="mw-redirect" title="Ombú">Ombú</a>. The surface soils of the pampa are a deep black color, primarily <a href="/wiki/Mollisols" class="mw-redirect" title="Mollisols">mollisols</a>, known commonly as <i>humus</i>. This makes the region one of the most agriculturally productive on Earth; however, this is also responsible for decimating much of the original ecosystem, to make way for commercial agriculture. The western pampas receive less rainfall, this <i>dry pampa</i> is a plain of short grasses or <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="National Parks of Argentina">National Parks of Argentina</a> make up a network of 35 <a href="/wiki/National_park" title="National park">national parks</a> in Argentina. The parks cover a very varied set of terrains and <a href="/wiki/Biotope" title="Biotope">biotopes</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Barit%C3%BA_National_Park" title="Baritú National Park">Baritú National Park</a> on the northern border with <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> to <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego_National_Park" title="Tierra del Fuego National Park">Tierra del Fuego National Park</a> in the far south of the continent. The <a href="/wiki/Administraci%C3%B3n_de_Parques_Nacionales" title="Administración de Parques Nacionales">Administración de Parques Nacionales</a> (National Parks Administration) is the agency that preserves and manages these national parks along with <a href="/wiki/Natural_monument" title="Natural monument">Natural monuments</a> and <a href="/wiki/National_Reserve" title="National Reserve">National Reserves</a> within the country.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.21/10, ranking it 47<sup>th</sup> globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-155">[143]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Argentina" title="Climate of Argentina">Climate of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climatic_regions_of_Argentina" title="Climatic regions of Argentina">Climatic regions of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG/220px-Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG/330px-Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG/440px-Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1333"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Perito_Moreno_Glacier_Patagonia_Argentina_Luca_Galuzzi_2005.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Argentina features geographical locations such as this glacier, known as the <a href="/wiki/Perito_Moreno_Glacier" title="Perito Moreno Glacier">Perito Moreno Glacier</a><sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[144]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In general, Argentina has four main climate types: warm, moderate, arid, and cold, all determined by the expanse across latitude, range in altitude, and relief features.<sup id="cite_ref-arggov_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arggov-157">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[146]</a></sup> Although the most populated areas are generally <a href="/wiki/Temperate_climate" title="Temperate climate">temperate</a>, Argentina has an exceptional amount of climate diversity,<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-159">[147]</a></sup> ranging from <a href="/wiki/Subtropical" class="mw-redirect" title="Subtropical">subtropical</a> in the north to <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar</a> in the far south.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[148]</a></sup> Consequently, there is a wide variety of <a href="/wiki/Biomes" class="mw-redirect" title="Biomes">biomes</a> in the country, including subtropical rain forests, semi-arid and <a href="/wiki/Arid" title="Arid">arid</a> regions, temperate plains in the Pampas, and cold subantarctic in the south.<sup id="cite_ref-Fernandez_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fernandez-161">[149]</a></sup> The average annual precipitation ranges from 150 millimetres (6&nbsp;in) in the driest parts of <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a> to over 2,000 millimetres (79&nbsp;in) in the westernmost parts of Patagonia and the northeastern parts of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_159-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-159">[147]</a></sup> Mean annual temperatures range from 5&nbsp;°C (41&nbsp;°F) in the far south to 25&nbsp;°C (77&nbsp;°F) in the north.<sup id="cite_ref-FAO_159-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO-159">[147]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Major wind currents include the cool <a href="/wiki/Pampero_Winds" class="mw-redirect" title="Pampero Winds">Pampero Winds</a> blowing on the flat plains of Patagonia and the Pampas; following the cold front, warm currents blow from the north in middle and late winter, creating mild conditions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069-162">[150]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sudestada" title="Sudestada">Sudestada</a> usually moderates cold temperatures but brings very heavy rains, rough seas and <a href="/wiki/Coastal_flooding" title="Coastal flooding">coastal flooding</a>. It is most common in late autumn and winter along the central coast and in the Río de la Plata estuary.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198069-162">[150]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Zonda_wind" title="Zonda wind">Zonda</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Foehn_wind" title="Foehn wind">hot dry wind</a>, affects Cuyo and the central Pampas. Squeezed of all moisture during the 6,000&nbsp;m (19,685&nbsp;ft) descent from the Andes, Zonda winds can blow for hours with gusts up to 120&nbsp;km/h (75&nbsp;mph), fueling wildfires and causing damage; between June and November, when the Zonda blows, snowstorms and <a href="/wiki/Blizzard" title="Blizzard">blizzard</a> (<i>viento blanco</i>) conditions usually affect higher elevations.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198053_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMenuttiMenutti198053-163">[151]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Argentina" title="Climate change in Argentina">Climate change in Argentina</a> is predicted to have significant effects on the living conditions in <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Argentina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cambioclimatico2009_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cambioclimatico2009-164">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:<span>30</span></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Argentina" title="Climate of Argentina">climate of Argentina</a> is changing with regards to precipitation patterns and temperatures. The highest increases in the precipitation (from the period 1960–2010) have occurred in the eastern parts of the country. The increase in precipitation has led to more variability in precipitation from year to year in the northern parts of the country, with a higher risk of prolonged <a href="/wiki/Droughts" class="mw-redirect" title="Droughts">droughts</a>, disfavoring agriculture in these <a href="/wiki/Regions" class="mw-redirect" title="Regions">regions</a>. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Argentina" title="Politics of Argentina">Politics of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the 20th century, Argentina experienced significant political turmoil and democratic reversals.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson_165-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-165">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-166">[154]</a></sup> Between 1930 and 1976, the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic">armed forces</a> overthrew six governments in Argentina;<sup id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_166-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-166">[154]</a></sup> and the country alternated periods of democracy (1912–1930, 1946–1955, and 1973–1976) with periods of restricted democracy and <a href="/wiki/Military_regime" class="mw-redirect" title="Military regime">military rule</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson_165-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-165">[153]</a></sup> Following a <a href="/wiki/Transition_to_democracy" class="mw-redirect" title="Transition to democracy">transition</a> that began in 1983,<sup id="cite_ref-Anderson_167-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Anderson-167">[155]</a></sup> full-scale democracy in Argentina was reestablished.<sup id="cite_ref-Robinson_165-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Robinson-165">[153]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_166-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-166">[154]</a></sup> Argentina's democracy endured through the <a href="/wiki/1998%E2%80%932002_Argentine_great_depression" title="1998–2002 Argentine great depression">2001–02 crisis</a> and to the present day; it is regarded as more robust than both its pre-1983 predecessors and other democracies in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LevitskyMurillo_166-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LevitskyMurillo-166">[154]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Argentina" title="Government of Argentina">Government of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministries_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Ministries of the Argentine Republic">Ministries of the Argentine Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG/220px-Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG/330px-Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG/440px-Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3433" data-file-height="1785"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Panorama_Casa_Gobierno_Argentina.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Casa_Rosada" title="Casa Rosada">Casa Rosada</a>, workplace of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentina is a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> constitutional republic and <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._1_168-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._1-168">[156]</a></sup> The government is regulated by a system of <a href="/wiki/Separation_of_powers" title="Separation of powers">checks and balances</a> defined by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Argentina" title="Constitution of Argentina">Constitution of Argentina</a>, the country's supreme legal document. The <a href="/wiki/Seat_of_government" title="Seat of government">seat of government</a> is the city of <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, as designated by <a href="/wiki/Argentine_National_Congress" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine National Congress">Congress</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._3_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._3-23">[18]</a></sup> Suffrage is <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Equal_suffrage" class="mw-redirect" title="Equal suffrage">equal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Secret_ballot" title="Secret ballot">secret</a> and <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_voting" title="Compulsory voting">mandatory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._37_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._37-169">[157]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[J]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The federal government is composed of three branches: </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg/220px-BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg/330px-BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg/440px-BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1581" data-file-height="1184"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:BuenosAires_Palacio_del_Congreso.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Argentina" title="National Congress of Argentina">National Congress</a> composed of the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Senate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Chamber_of_Deputies" title="Argentine Chamber of Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._63_172-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._63-172">[159]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Legislature" title="Legislature">Legislative</a> branch consists of the <a href="/wiki/Bicameralism" title="Bicameralism">bicameral</a> Congress, made up of the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Senate</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Chamber_of_Deputies" title="Argentine Chamber of Deputies">Chamber of Deputies</a>. The Congress makes <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves <a href="/wiki/Treaty" title="Treaty">treaties</a> and has the <a href="/wiki/Power_of_the_purse" title="Power of the purse">power of the purse</a> and of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a>, by which it can remove sitting members of the government.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._53,_59,_75_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._53,_59,_75-173">[160]</a></sup> The Chamber of Deputies represents the people and has 257 voting members elected to a four-year term. Seats are apportioned among the provinces by population every tenth year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._45,_47,_50_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._45,_47,_50-174">[161]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> ten provinces have just five deputies while the <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Province" title="Buenos Aires Province">Buenos Aires Province</a>, being the most populous one, has 70. The Chamber of Senators represents the provinces, has 72 members elected <a href="/wiki/At-large" title="At-large">at-large</a> to six-year terms, with each province having three seats; one third of Senate seats are up for election every other year.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._54,_56_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._54,_56-175">[162]</a></sup> At least one-third of the candidates presented by the parties must be women. </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">Executive</a> branch, the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the military, can <a href="/wiki/Veto" title="Veto">veto</a> <a href="/wiki/Bill_(law)" title="Bill (law)">legislative bills</a> before they become law—subject to Congressional override—and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Cabinet of Argentina">members of the Cabinet</a> and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._99_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._99-176">[163]</a></sup> The President is elected <a href="/wiki/Direct_vote" class="mw-redirect" title="Direct vote">directly</a> by the vote of the people, serves a four-year term and may be elected to office no more than twice in a row.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._90_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._90-177">[164]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">Judicial</a> branch includes the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Argentina" title="Supreme Court of Argentina">Supreme Court</a> and lower <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Law of Argentina">federal courts</a> interpret laws and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_review" title="Judicial review">overturn those</a> they find <a href="/wiki/Constitutionality" title="Constitutionality">unconstitutional</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._116_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._116-178">[165]</a></sup> The Judicial is independent of the Executive and the Legislative. The Supreme Court has seven members appointed by the President—subject to Senate approval—who serve for life. The lower courts' judges are proposed by the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Magistracy_of_the_Nation" title="Council of Magistracy of the Nation">Council of Magistracy</a> (a secretariat composed of representatives of judges, lawyers, researchers, the Executive and the Legislative), and appointed by the President on Senate approval.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._99,_114_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._99,_114-179">[166]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Provinces">Provinces</span></h3> 
      <p>Argentina is a federation of twenty-three provinces and one <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_city" title="Autonomous city">autonomous city</a>, Buenos Aires. Provinces are divided for administration purposes into <a href="/wiki/Departments_of_Argentina" title="Departments of Argentina">departments</a> and <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Argentina" title="Municipalities of Argentina">municipalities</a>, except for Buenos Aires Province, which is divided into <a href="/wiki/Partidos_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Partidos of Buenos Aires">partidos</a>. The City of Buenos Aires is divided into <a href="/wiki/Barrios_and_Communes_of_Buenos_Aires" class="mw-redirect" title="Barrios and Communes of Buenos Aires">communes</a>. </p>
      <p>Provinces hold all the power that they chose not to delegate to the federal government;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._121_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._121-180">[167]</a></sup> they must be representative republics and must not contradict the Constitution.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._5–6_181-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._5–6-181">[168]</a></sup> Beyond this they are fully autonomous: they enact their own constitutions,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._123_182-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._123-182">[169]</a></sup> freely organize their local governments,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._122_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._122-183">[170]</a></sup> and own and manage their natural and financial resources.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._124–125_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._124–125-184">[171]</a></sup> Some provinces have bicameral legislatures, while others have <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> ones.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[K]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the War of Independence the main cities and their surrounding countrysides became provinces though the intervention of their <a href="/wiki/Cabildo_(council)" title="Cabildo (council)">cabildos</a>. The Anarchy of the Year XX completed this process, shaping the original thirteen provinces. Jujuy seceded from <a href="/wiki/Salta_Province" title="Salta Province">Salta</a> in 1834, and the thirteen provinces became fourteen. After seceding for a decade, Buenos Aires accepted the 1853 Constitution of Argentina in 1861, and was made a federal territory in 1880.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-187">[173]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>An 1862 law designated as <a href="/wiki/National_territory" class="mw-redirect" title="National territory">national territories</a> those under federal control but outside the frontiers of the provinces. In 1884 they served as bases for the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Governorate" title="Governorate">governorates</a> of Misiones, Formosa, Chaco, La Pampa, Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERock1987155_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERock1987155-188">[174]</a></sup> The agreement about a frontier dispute with Chile in 1900 created the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Territory_of_Los_Andes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Territory of Los Andes (page does not exist)">National Territory of Los Andes</a>; its lands were incorporated into Jujuy, Salta and <a href="/wiki/Catamarca_Province" title="Catamarca Province">Catamarca</a> in 1943.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-187">[173]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/La_Pampa_Province" title="La Pampa Province">La Pampa</a> and Chaco became provinces in 1951. Misiones did so in 1953, and <a href="/wiki/Formosa_Province" title="Formosa Province">Formosa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neuqu%C3%A9n_Province" title="Neuquén Province">Neuquén</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%C3%ADo_Negro_Province" title="Río Negro Province">Río Negro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chubut_Province" title="Chubut Province">Chubut</a> and Santa Cruz, in 1955. The last national territory, Tierra del Fuego, became the <a href="/wiki/Tierra_del_Fuego,_Ant%C3%A1rtida_e_Islas_del_Atl%C3%A1ntico_Sur_Province" class="mw-redirect" title="Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province">Tierra del Fuego, Antártida e Islas del Atlántico Sur Province</a> in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519_187-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERey_Balmaceda199519-187">[173]</a></sup> It has three components, although two are nominal because they are not under Argentine sovereignty. The first is the Argentine part of Tierra del Fuego; the second is an area of Antarctica claimed by Argentina that overlaps with similar areas claimed by the UK and Chile; the third comprises the two disputed British Overseas Territories of the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Duggan_and_Lewis_189-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Duggan_and_Lewis-189">[175]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Argentina" title="Foreign relations of Argentina">Foreign relations of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:G20_Argentina_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Presidents all standing together." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/220px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="104" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/330px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/G20_Argentina_2018.jpg/440px-G20_Argentina_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4459" data-file-height="2114"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:G20_Argentina_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G 20</a> leaders gathered in Argentina for the <a href="/wiki/2018_G20_Buenos_Aires_summit" title="2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit">2018 G20 Buenos Aires summit</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Foreign policy is handled by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs,_International_Trade_and_Worship" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship">Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship</a>, which answers to the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Argentina" title="President of Argentina">President</a>. </p>
      <p>The country is one of the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_15" title="Group of 15">G-15</a> and <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a> of the world, and a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/UN" class="mw-redirect" title="UN">UN</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank_Group" title="World Bank Group">WBG</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a> and <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">OAS</a>. In 2012 <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_election,_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Security Council election, 2012">Argentina was elected again</a> to a two-year non-permanent position on the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and is participating in major peacekeeping operations in <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Stabilization_Mission_in_Haiti" class="mw-redirect" title="United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Peacekeeping_Force_in_Cyprus" title="United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">Western Sahara</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[176]</a></sup> Argentina is described as a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood198818Solomon19973-37">[32]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Cooper_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cooper-191">[177]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A prominent Latin American<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHuntington20006Nierop200161Lake200955Papadopoulos2010283Malamud20119Boughton2012101-38">[33]</a></sup> and Southern Cone<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918_39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorris198863AdlerGreve200978Ruiz-DanaGoldschagClaroBlanco200918-39">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a>, Argentina co-founded <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">OEI</a> and <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">CELAC</a>. It is also a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a> block, having Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">Venezuela</a> as partners. Since 2002 the country has emphasized its key role in <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_integration" title="Latin American integration">Latin American integration</a>, and the block—which has some supranational legislative functions—is its first international priority.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011600vol._II_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGalasso2011600vol._II-192">[178]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/300px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/450px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png/600px-Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png 2x" data-file-width="1425" data-file-height="625"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_of_Argentina" title="List of diplomatic missions of Argentina">Diplomatic missions of Argentina</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentina claims 965,597&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (372,819&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) in <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Antarctica" title="Argentine Antarctica">Antarctica</a>, where it has the world's oldest <a href="/wiki/Orcadas_Base" title="Orcadas Base">continuous state presence</a>, since 1904.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[179]</a></sup> This overlaps claims by <a href="/wiki/Chilean_Antarctic_Territory" title="Chilean Antarctic Territory">Chile</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">United Kingdom</a>, though all such claims fall under the provisions of the 1961 <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Antarctic Treaty">Antarctic Treaty</a>, of which Argentina is a founding signatory and permanent consulting member, with the <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_Secretariat" title="Antarctic Treaty Secretariat">Antarctic Treaty Secretariat</a> being based in Buenos Aires.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" title="Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute">disputes sovereignty</a> over the Falkland Islands (Spanish: <i lang="es">Islas Malvinas</i>), and <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_South_Sandwich_Islands_sovereignty_dispute" class="mw-redirect" title="South Georgia and South Sandwich Islands sovereignty dispute">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_ArgentinaT._P._1_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_ArgentinaT._P._1-195">[181]</a></sup> which are administered by the United Kingdom as <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">Overseas Territories</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Armed_forces">Armed forces</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_the_Argentine_Republic" title="Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic">Armed Forces of the Argentine Republic</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The President holds the title of commander-in-chief of the Argentine Armed Forces, as part of a legal framework that imposes a strict separation between national defense and internal security systems:<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-lsi_197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-197">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Argentine_defense_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine defense industry">National Defense System</a>, an exclusive responsibility of the federal government,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._125–126_198-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._125–126-198">[184]</a></sup> coordinated by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Argentina)" title="Ministry of Defense (Argentina)">Ministry of Defense</a>, and comprising the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Army" title="Argentine Army">Army</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Navy" title="Argentine Navy">Navy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Air_Force" title="Argentine Air Force">Air Force</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[185]</a></sup> Ruled and monitored by Congress<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._21,_75,_99_200-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._21,_75,_99-200">[186]</a></sup> through the Houses' Defense Committees,<sup id="cite_ref-resdal_201-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-201">[187]</a></sup> it is organized on the essential principle of legitimate self-defense: the repelling of any external military aggression in order to guarantee freedom of the people, national sovereignty, and territorial integrity.<sup id="cite_ref-resdal_201-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-201">[187]</a></sup> Its secondary missions include committing to multinational operations within the framework of the United Nations, participating in internal support missions, assisting friendly countries, and establishing a sub-regional defense system.<sup id="cite_ref-resdal_201-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-resdal-201">[187]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="210" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="898" data-file-height="1108"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ARA_Almirante_Brown_D_10_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Argentine destroyer <a href="/wiki/ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)" title="ARA Almirante Brown (D-10)">ARA <i>Almirante Brown</i> (D-10)</a><sup id="cite_ref-ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)_202-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ARA_Almirante_Brown_(D-10)-202">[188]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Military_service" title="Military service">Military service</a> is voluntary, with enlistment age between 18 and 24 years old and no <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">conscription</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[189]</a></sup> Argentina's defense has historically been one of the best equipped in the region, even managing <a href="/wiki/Argentine_defense_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine defense industry">its own weapon research facilities, shipyards, ordnance, tank and plane factories</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMaldifassiAbetti199465–86_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMaldifassiAbetti199465–86-204">[190]</a></sup> However, real military expenditures declined steadily after 1981 and the defense budget in 2011 was about 0.74% of GDP, a historical minimum,<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[191]</a></sup> below the Latin American average. Within the defence budget itself funding for training and even basic maintenance has been significantly cut, a factor contributing to the <a href="/wiki/Disappearance_of_ARA_San_Juan" title="Disappearance of ARA San Juan">accidental loss of the Argentine submarine San Juan</a> in 2017. With the United Kingdom also actively acting to restrict even modest Argentinian military modernization efforts,<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[192]</a></sup> the result has been a steady erosion of Argentine military capabilities, with some arguing that Argentina had, by the end of the 2010s, ceased to be a capable military power.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Interior_Security_System" title="Argentine Interior Security System">Interior Security System</a>, jointly administered by the federal and subscribing provincial governments.<sup id="cite_ref-lsi_197-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-197">[183]</a></sup> At the federal level it is coordinated by the Interior, <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Argentina)" title="Ministry of Defense (Argentina)">Security</a> and Justice ministries, and monitored by Congress.<sup id="cite_ref-lsi_197-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-197">[183]</a></sup> It is enforced by the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Federal_Police" title="Argentine Federal Police">Federal Police</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Naval_Prefecture" title="Argentine Naval Prefecture">Prefecture</a>, which fulfills <a href="/wiki/Coast_guard" title="Coast guard">coast guard</a> duties; the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_National_Gendarmerie" title="Argentine National Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a>, which serves <a href="/wiki/Border_guard" title="Border guard">border guard</a> tasks; and the <a href="/wiki/Airport_Security_Police_(Argentina)" title="Airport Security Police (Argentina)">Airport Security Police</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[194]</a></sup> At the provincial level it is coordinated by the respective internal security ministries and enforced by local police agencies.<sup id="cite_ref-lsi_197-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lsi-197">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina was the only South American country to send warships and cargo planes in 1991 to the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_War" title="Gulf War">Gulf War</a> under <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a> mandate and has remained involved in <a href="/wiki/Peacekeeping" title="Peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> efforts in multiple locations like <a href="/wiki/UNPROFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="UNPROFOR">UNPROFOR</a> in <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>/<a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Fonseca" title="Gulf of Fonseca">Gulf of Fonseca</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Peacekeeping_Force_in_Cyprus" title="United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus">UNFICYP</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> (where among Army and Marines troops the Air Force provided the UN Air contingent since 1994) and <a href="/wiki/MINUSTAH" class="mw-redirect" title="MINUSTAH">MINUSTAH</a> in <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>. Argentina is the only Latin American country to maintain troops in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> during <a href="/wiki/SFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="SFOR">SFOR</a> (and later <a href="/wiki/EUFOR" class="mw-redirect" title="EUFOR">EUFOR</a>) operations where <a href="/wiki/Combat_engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Combat engineering">combat engineers</a> of the Argentine Armed Forces are embedded in an <a href="/wiki/Italian_Army" title="Italian Army">Italian brigade</a>. </p>
      <p>In 2007, an Argentine contingent including helicopters, boats and water purification plants was sent to help <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a> against their worst floods in decades.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[195]</a></sup> In 2010 the Armed Forces were also involved in <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_response_by_national_governments_to_the_2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="Humanitarian response by national governments to the 2010 Haiti earthquake">Haiti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Humanitarian_response_to_the_2010_Chile_earthquake" title="Humanitarian response to the 2010 Chile earthquake">Chile</a> humanitarian responses after their respective earthquakes. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Argentina" title="Economy of Argentina">Economy of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Argentine_foreign_trade" class="mw-redirect" title="Argentine foreign trade">Argentine foreign trade</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Field" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/170px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/255px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg/340px-Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3504" data-file-height="4108"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Bodega_chakana_hacia_la_monta%C3%B1a.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Argentina" title="Agriculture in Argentina">Argentine agriculture</a> is relatively capital intensive, today providing about 7% of all employment.<sup id="cite_ref-mecon_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mecon-210">[196]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Benefiting from rich <a href="/wiki/Natural_resources" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural resources">natural resources</a>, a highly literate population, a diversified industrial base, and an export-oriented agricultural sector, the economy of Argentina is Latin America's third-largest,<sup id="cite_ref-wsj1_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wsj1-211">[197]</a></sup> and the second largest in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[198]</a></sup> It has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">"very high"</a> rating on the Human Development Index<sup id="cite_ref-UNHDR_21-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNHDR-21">[17]</a></sup> and a relatively <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)_per_capita" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP) per capita">high GDP per capita</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-213">[199]</a></sup> with a considerable <a href="/wiki/Internal_market" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal market">internal market</a> size and a growing share of the high-tech sector. </p>
      <p>Access to <a href="/wiki/Biocapacity" title="Biocapacity">biocapacity</a> in Argentina is much higher than world average. In 2016, Argentina had 6.8 global hectares<sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_214-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-214">[200]</a></sup> of biocapacity per person within its territory, much more than the world average of 1.6 global hectares per person.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[201]</a></sup> In 2016 Argentina used 3.4 global hectares of biocapacity per person – their <a href="/wiki/Ecological_footprint" title="Ecological footprint">ecological footprint</a> of consumption. This means they use half as much biocapacity as Argentina contains. As a result, Argentina is running a biocapacity reserve.<sup id="cite_ref-footprintdata_214-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-footprintdata-214">[200]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Microcentro,_Buenos_Aires_(40774240522).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/220px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/330px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg/440px-Microcentro%2C_Buenos_Aires_%2840774240522%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3565" data-file-height="3688"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Microcentro,_Buenos_Aires_(40774240522).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Catalinas_Norte" title="Catalinas Norte">Catalinas Norte</a> is an important business complex composed of nineteen commercial office buildings and occupied by numerous leading Argentine companies.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Emerging_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Emerging economy">middle emerging economy</a> and one of the world's top developing nations,<sup id="cite_ref-undp2013_216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-undp2013-216">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[L]</a></sup> Argentina is a member of the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G-20 major economies</a>. Historically, however, its economic performance has been very uneven, with high economic growth alternating with severe recessions, income maldistribution and—in the recent decades—increasing poverty. Early in the 20th century Argentina achieved development,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701_31-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDíaz_Alejandro19701-31">[26]</a></sup> and became the world's seventh richest country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_30-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-30">[25]</a></sup> Although managing to keep a place among the top fifteen economies until mid-century,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013_30-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoltVan_Zanden2013-30">[25]</a></sup> it suffered a long and steady decline, but it is still a high income country.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[203]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>High <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a>—a weakness of the Argentine economy for decades—has become a trouble once again,<sup id="cite_ref-nyt-2011-02-06_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-2011-02-06-219">[204]</a></sup> with an annual rate of 24.8% in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-Official_INDEC_consumer_price_index_figures_(Spanish)_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Official_INDEC_consumer_price_index_figures_(Spanish)-220">[205]</a></sup> To deter it and support the peso, the government imposed foreign currency control.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[206]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Income_distribution" title="Income distribution">Income distribution</a>, having improved since 2002, is classified as "medium", although it is still considerably unequal.<sup id="cite_ref-gini_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gini-20">[16]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina ranks 85th out of 180 countries in the <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s 2017 <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[207]</a></sup> an improvement of 22 positions over its 2014 rankings.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[208]</a></sup> Argentina settled its long-standing debt default crisis in 2016 with the so-called <a href="/wiki/Vulture_funds" class="mw-redirect" title="Vulture funds">vulture funds</a> after the election of Mauricio Macri, allowing Argentina to enter capital markets for the first time in a decade.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[209]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The government of Argentina defaulted on 22 May 2020 by failing to pay a $500&nbsp;million due date to its creditors. Negotiations for the restructuring of $66&nbsp;billion of its debt continue.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[210]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry">Industry</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Industry_in_Argentina" title="Industry in Argentina">Industry in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/220px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/330px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg/440px-Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg 2x" data-file-width="604" data-file-height="574"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Montaje_de_Atucha_II.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha Nuclear Power Plant</a> was the first nuclear power plant in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[211]</a></sup> The electricity comes from 3 operational <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_reactor" title="Nuclear reactor">nuclear reactors</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Embalse_Nuclear_Power_Station" title="Embalse Nuclear Power Station">Embalse Nuclear Power Station</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha I</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atucha_II_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Atucha II Nuclear Power Plant">II</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing" title="Manufacturing">manufacturing</a> accounted for 20.3% of GDP—the largest sector in the nation's economy.<sup id="cite_ref-infoeco1_227-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-227">[212]</a></sup> Well-integrated into Argentine agriculture, half of the industrial exports have rural origin.<sup id="cite_ref-infoeco1_227-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-227">[212]</a></sup> </p>
