      <p>With a 6.5% production growth rate in 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[213]</a></sup> the diversified manufacturing sector rests on a steadily growing network of <a href="/wiki/Industrial_park" title="Industrial park">industrial parks</a> (314 as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>)<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[214]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[215]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the leading sectors by volume were: food processing, beverages and tobacco products; motor vehicles and auto parts; <a href="/wiki/Textiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Textiles">textiles</a> and leather; <a href="/wiki/Petroleum_refineries" class="mw-redirect" title="Petroleum refineries">refinery products</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biodiesel" title="Biodiesel">biodiesel</a>; chemicals and pharmaceuticals; steel, aluminum and iron; industrial and farm machinery; home appliances and furniture; plastics and tires; glass and cement; and recording and print media.<sup id="cite_ref-infoeco1_227-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-227">[212]</a></sup> In addition, Argentina has since long been one of the top five wine-producing countries in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-infoeco1_227-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-infoeco1-227">[212]</a></sup> However, it has also been classified as one of the 74 countries where instances of <a href="/wiki/Child_labour" title="Child labour">child labour</a> and <a href="/wiki/Forced_labour" class="mw-redirect" title="Forced labour">forced labour</a> have been observed and mentioned in a 2014 report published by the <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_International_Labor_Affairs" title="Bureau of International Labor Affairs">Bureau of International Labor Affairs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ilab_231-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ilab-231">[216]</a></sup> The ILAB's <i><a href="/wiki/List_of_Goods_Produced_by_Child_Labor_or_Forced_Labor" title="List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor">List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor</a></i> shows that many of the goods produced by child labour or forced labour comes from the <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Argentina" title="Agriculture in Argentina">agricultural sector</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ilab_231-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ilab-231">[216]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Córdoba is Argentina's major industrial centre, hosting metalworking, motor vehicle and auto parts manufactures. Next in importance are the <a href="/wiki/Greater_Buenos_Aires" title="Greater Buenos Aires">Greater Buenos Aires</a> area (food processing, metallurgy, motor vehicles and auto parts, chemicals and petrochemicals, consumer durables, textiles and printing); <a href="/wiki/Rosario" class="mw-redirect" title="Rosario">Rosario</a> (food processing, metallurgy, farm machinery, oil refining, chemicals, and tanning); San Miguel de Tucumán (sugar refining); <a href="/wiki/San_Lorenzo,_Santa_Fe" title="San Lorenzo, Santa Fe">San Lorenzo</a> (chemicals and pharmaceuticals); <a href="/wiki/San_Nicol%C3%A1s_de_los_Arroyos" title="San Nicolás de los Arroyos">San Nicolás de los Arroyos</a> (steel milling and metallurgy); and <a href="/wiki/Ushuaia" title="Ushuaia">Ushuaia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%ADa_Blanca" title="Bahía Blanca">Bahía Blanca</a> (oil refining).<sup id="cite_ref-eotn2_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn2-232">[217]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (April 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup> Other manufacturing enterprises are located in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Santa_Fe_Province" title="Santa Fe Province">Santa Fe</a> (zinc and copper smelting, and flour milling); Mendoza and Neuquén (wineries and fruit processing); Chaco (textiles and sawmills); and Santa Cruz, Salta and Chubut (oil refining).<sup id="cite_ref-eotn2_232-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn2-232">[217]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources"><span title="The material near this tag may rely on an unreliable source. (April 2018)">unreliable source?</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The electric output of Argentina in 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> totaled over 122&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Watt-hour" class="mw-redirect" title="Watt-hour">TWh</a> (440&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Joule" title="Joule">PJ</a>), of which about 37% was consumed by industrial activities.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[218]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Argentina" title="Transport in Argentina">Transport in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:219px;max-width:219px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/215px-199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg" decoding="async" width="215" height="87" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/323px-199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg/430px-199_-_Buenos_Aires_-_A%C3%A9roport_international_Ezeiza_-_Janvier_2010.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6936" data-file-height="2800"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:217px;max-width:217px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Ezeizaaero.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ezeizaaero.jpg/215px-Ezeizaaero.jpg" decoding="async" width="215" height="143" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ezeizaaero.jpg/323px-Ezeizaaero.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Ezeizaaero.jpg/430px-Ezeizaaero.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="499"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Ministro_Pistarini_International_Airport" title="Ministro Pistarini International Airport">Ministro Pistarini International Airport</a> opened in 1949.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentina has the largest <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Argentina" title="Rail transport in Argentina">railway system</a> in Latin America, with 36,966&nbsp;km (22,970&nbsp;mi) of operating lines in 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, out of a full network of almost 48,000&nbsp;km (29,826&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[219]</a></sup> This system links all 23 provinces plus Buenos Aires City, and connects with all neighbouring countries.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> There are four incompatible <a href="/wiki/Track_gauge" title="Track gauge">gauges</a> in use; this forces virtually all interregional freight traffic to pass through Buenos Aires.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> The system has been in decline since the 1940s: regularly running up large budgetary deficits, by 1991 it was transporting 1,400 times less goods than it did in 1973.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> However, in recent years the system has experienced a <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Argentina#Recent_developments_and_moves_towards_re-nationalisation" title="Rail transport in Argentina">greater degree of investment</a> from the state, in both commuter rail lines and long-distance lines, renewing rolling stock and infrastructure.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[222]</a></sup> In April 2015, by overwhelming majority the <a href="/wiki/Argentine_Senate" title="Argentine Senate">Argentine Senate</a> passed a law which re-created <a href="/wiki/Ferrocarriles_Argentinos" title="Ferrocarriles Argentinos">Ferrocarriles Argentinos</a> (2015), effectively re-nationalising the country's railways, a move which saw support from all major political parties on both sides of the political spectrum.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[224]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[225]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Underground railway." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg/220px-200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="110" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg/330px-200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg/440px-200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg 2x" data-file-width="700" data-file-height="350"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:200_Series_at_San_Jos%C3%A9_de_Flores.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Underground" title="Buenos Aires Underground">Buenos Aires Underground</a> is the oldest underground railway in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Spanish speaking world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[226]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>By 2004<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Buenos Aires, all provincial capitals except Ushuaia, and all medium-sized towns were interconnected by 69,412&nbsp;km (43,131&nbsp;mi) of paved roads, out of a total road network of 231,374&nbsp;km (143,769&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[227]</a></sup> Most important cities are linked by a growing number of <a href="/wiki/Controlled-access_highway" title="Controlled-access highway">expressways</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires-La_Plata_Highway" class="mw-redirect" title="Buenos Aires-La Plata Highway">Buenos Aires–La Plata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rosario-C%C3%B3rdoba_Highway" title="Rosario-Córdoba Highway">Rosario–Córdoba</a>, Córdoba–Villa Carlos Paz, Villa Mercedes–Mendoza, <a href="/wiki/National_Route_14" class="mw-redirect" title="National Route 14">National Route 14</a> <i>General José Gervasio Artigas</i> and <a href="/wiki/Provincial_Route_2_(Buenos_Aires)" title="Provincial Route 2 (Buenos Aires)">Provincial Route 2 <i>Juan Manuel Fangio</i></a>, among others. Nevertheless, this road infrastructure is still inadequate and cannot handle the sharply growing demand caused by deterioration of the railway system.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were about 11,000&nbsp;km (6,835&nbsp;mi) of <a href="/wiki/Waterway" title="Waterway">waterways</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[228]</a></sup> mostly comprising the La Plata, Paraná, Paraguay and Uruguay rivers, with Buenos Aires, <a href="/wiki/Z%C3%A1rate,_Buenos_Aires" title="Zárate, Buenos Aires">Zárate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Campana,_Buenos_Aires" title="Campana, Buenos Aires">Campana</a>, Rosario, San Lorenzo, Santa Fe, <a href="/wiki/Barranqueras" title="Barranqueras">Barranqueras</a> and San Nicolas de los Arroyos as the main <a href="/wiki/Fluvial_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Fluvial port">fluvial ports</a>. Some of the largest <a href="/wiki/Sea_port" class="mw-redirect" title="Sea port">sea ports</a> are <a href="/wiki/La_Plata" title="La Plata">La Plata</a>–<a href="/wiki/Ensenada,_Buenos_Aires" title="Ensenada, Buenos Aires">Ensenada</a>, Bahía Blanca, <a href="/wiki/Mar_del_Plata" title="Mar del Plata">Mar del Plata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quequ%C3%A9n" title="Quequén">Quequén</a>–<a href="/wiki/Necochea" title="Necochea">Necochea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Comodoro_Rivadavia" title="Comodoro Rivadavia">Comodoro Rivadavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Deseado" title="Puerto Deseado">Puerto Deseado</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Madryn" title="Puerto Madryn">Puerto Madryn</a>, Ushuaia and <a href="/wiki/San_Antonio_Oeste" title="San Antonio Oeste">San Antonio Oeste</a>. Buenos Aires has historically been the most important port; however since the 1990s the Up-River port region has become dominant: stretching along 67&nbsp;km (42&nbsp;mi) of the Paraná river shore in Santa Fe province, it includes 17 ports and in 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> accounted for 50% of all exports. </p>
      <p>In 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 161 airports with paved runways<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[229]</a></sup> out of more than a thousand.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ezeiza_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Ezeiza International Airport">Ezeiza International Airport</a>, about 35&nbsp;km (22&nbsp;mi) from downtown Buenos Aires,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200076_245-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200076-245">[230]</a></sup> is the largest in the country, followed by <a href="/wiki/Cataratas_del_Iguaz%C3%BA_International_Airport" title="Cataratas del Iguazú International Airport">Cataratas del Iguazú</a> in Misiones, and <a href="/wiki/El_Plumerillo_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="El Plumerillo International Airport">El Plumerillo</a> in Mendoza.<sup id="cite_ref-eotn1_235-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotn1-235">[220]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aeroparque" class="mw-redirect" title="Aeroparque">Aeroparque</a>, in the city of Buenos Aires, is the most important domestic airport.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200024–25_246-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200024–25-246">[231]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_communications">Media and communications</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Communications_in_Argentina" title="Communications in Argentina">Communications in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Estudio_Pais1.JPG" class="image"><img alt="TV Studio." src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/220px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/330px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Estudio_Pais1.JPG/440px-Estudio_Pais1.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2272" data-file-height="1704"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Estudio_Pais1.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>"<i>Estudio País 24, the Program of the Argentines</i>" in <a href="/wiki/TV_P%C3%BAblica_Digital_(Argentina)" class="mw-redirect" title="TV Pública Digital (Argentina)">Channel 7</a>, the first television station in the country
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Print media industry is highly developed in Argentina, with more than two hundred newspapers. The major national ones include <i><a href="/wiki/Clar%C3%ADn_(Argentine_newspaper)" title="Clarín (Argentine newspaper)">Clarín</a></i> (centrist, Latin America's best-seller and the second most widely circulated in the Spanish-speaking world), <i><a href="/wiki/La_Naci%C3%B3n_(Buenos_Aires)" class="mw-redirect" title="La Nación (Buenos Aires)">La Nación</a></i> (centre-right, published since 1870), <i><a href="/wiki/P%C3%A1gina/12" title="Página/12">Página/12</a></i> (leftist, founded in 1987), the <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires_Herald" title="Buenos Aires Herald">Buenos Aires Herald</a> (Latin America's most prestigious English language daily, liberal, dating back to 1876), <i><a href="/wiki/La_Voz_del_Interior" title="La Voz del Interior">La Voz del Interior</a></i> (centre, founded in 1904),<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200045_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips200045-247">[232]</a></sup> and the <i><a href="/wiki/Argentinisches_Tageblatt" title="Argentinisches Tageblatt">Argentinisches Tageblatt</a></i> (German weekly, liberal, published since 1878)<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkstinat201320_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkstinat201320-248">[233]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina began <a href="/wiki/History_of_radio" title="History of radio">the world's first regular radio broadcasting</a> on 27 August 1920, when <a href="/wiki/Richard_Wagner" title="Richard Wagner">Richard Wagner</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Parsifal" title="Parsifal">Parsifal</a></i> was aired by a team of medical students led by <a href="/wiki/Enrique_Tel%C3%A9maco_Susini" title="Enrique Telémaco Susini">Enrique Telémaco Susini</a> in Buenos Aires' <a href="/wiki/Teatro_Coliseo" title="Teatro Coliseo">Teatro Coliseo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[234]</a></sup> By 2002<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 260 <a href="/wiki/AM_broadcasting" title="AM broadcasting">AM</a> and 1150 <a href="/wiki/FM_broadcasting" title="FM broadcasting">FM</a> registered radio stations in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[235]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Argentina" title="Television in Argentina">Argentine television</a> industry is large, diverse and popular across Latin America, with many productions and <a href="/wiki/TV_format" title="TV format">TV formats</a> having been exported abroad. Since 1999 Argentines enjoy the highest availability of cable and satellite television in Latin America,<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[236]</a></sup> as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> totaling 87.4% of the country's households, a rate similar to those in the United States, Canada and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[237]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Argentina also had the highest coverage of networked telecommunications among Latin American powers: about 67% of its population had internet access and 137.2%, mobile phone subscriptions.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[238]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Argentina" title="Science and technology in Argentina">Science and technology in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_(201106100022HQ)_DVIDS722852.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Satellite launching" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg/170px-Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg/255px-Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg/340px-Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_%28201106100022HQ%29_DVIDS722852.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1576" data-file-height="2364"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Aquarius_SAC-D_Launch_(201106100022HQ)_DVIDS722852.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/SAC-D" title="SAC-D">SAC-D</a> is an Argentine earth science <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a> built by <a href="/wiki/INVAP" title="INVAP">INVAP</a> and launched in 2011.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentines have received three <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize" title="Nobel Prize">Nobel Prizes</a> in the Sciences. <a href="/wiki/Bernardo_Houssay" title="Bernardo Houssay">Bernardo Houssay</a>, the first Latin American recipient, discovered the role of <a href="/wiki/Pituitary_gland" title="Pituitary gland">pituitary hormones</a> in regulating <a href="/wiki/Glucose" title="Glucose">glucose</a> in animals, and shared the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Physiology_or_Medicine" title="Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine">Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine</a> in 1947. <a href="/wiki/Luis_Leloir" class="mw-redirect" title="Luis Leloir">Luis Leloir</a> discovered how organisms store energy converting glucose into <a href="/wiki/Glycogen" title="Glycogen">glycogen</a> and the compounds which are fundamental in <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolizing</a> <a href="/wiki/Carbohydrate" title="Carbohydrate">carbohydrates</a>, receiving the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Chemistry" title="Nobel Prize in Chemistry">Nobel Prize in Chemistry</a> in 1970. <a href="/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Milstein" title="César Milstein">César Milstein</a> did extensive research in <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">antibodies</a>, sharing the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1984. Argentine research has led to treatments for <a href="/wiki/Heart_disease" class="mw-redirect" title="Heart disease">heart diseases</a> and several forms of cancer. <a href="/wiki/Domingo_Liotta" title="Domingo Liotta">Domingo Liotta</a> designed and developed the first <a href="/wiki/Artificial_heart" title="Artificial heart">artificial heart</a> that was successfully implanted in a human being in 1969. <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Favaloro" title="René Favaloro">René Favaloro</a> developed the techniques and performed the world's first <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_bypass_surgery" title="Coronary artery bypass surgery">coronary bypass surgery</a>. </p>
      <p>Argentina's nuclear programme has been highly successful. In 1957 Argentina was the first country in Latin America to design and build a <a href="/wiki/Research_reactor" title="Research reactor">research reactor</a> with homegrown technology, the <a href="/wiki/RA-1_Enrico_Fermi" title="RA-1 Enrico Fermi">RA-1 Enrico Fermi</a>. This reliance in the development of own nuclear related technologies, instead of simply buying them abroad, was a constant of Argentina's nuclear programme conducted by the civilian <a href="/wiki/National_Atomic_Energy_Commission" title="National Atomic Energy Commission">National Atomic Energy Commission</a> (CNEA). Nuclear facilities with Argentine technology have been built in Peru, Algeria, Australia and Egypt. In 1983, the country admitted having the capability of producing weapon-grade <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, a major step needed to assemble <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapon" title="Nuclear weapon">nuclear weapons</a>; since then, however, Argentina has pledged to use nuclear power only for peaceful purposes.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[239]</a></sup> As a member of the Board of Governors of the <a href="/wiki/International_Atomic_Energy_Agency" title="International Atomic Energy Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a>, Argentina has been a strong voice in support of nuclear non-proliferation efforts<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[240]</a></sup> and is highly committed to global nuclear security.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[241]</a></sup> In 1974 it was the first country in Latin America to put in-line a commercial nuclear power plant, <a href="/wiki/Atucha_I_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Atucha I Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha I</a>. Although the Argentine built parts for that station amounted to 10% of the total, the nuclear fuel it uses are since entirely built in the country. Later nuclear power stations employed a higher percentage of Argentine built components; <a href="/wiki/Embalse_Nuclear_Power_Station" title="Embalse Nuclear Power Station">Embalse</a>, finished in 1983, a 30% and the 2011 <a href="/wiki/Atucha_II_Nuclear_Power_Plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Atucha II Nuclear Power Plant">Atucha II</a> reactor a 40%.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[242]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Team of astronauts" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/220px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/330px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg/440px-Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2000" data-file-height="1805"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Macri_sala_limpia_INVAP.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>President Macri in the <a href="/wiki/INVAP" title="INVAP">INVAP</a> with the <a href="/wiki/SAOCOM" title="SAOCOM">SAOCOM</a> A and B, two planned <a href="/wiki/Earth_observation_satellite" title="Earth observation satellite">Earth observation satellite</a> <a href="/wiki/Satellite_constellation" title="Satellite constellation">constellation</a> of Argentine <a href="/wiki/Space_Agency" class="mw-redirect" title="Space Agency">Space Agency</a> <a href="/wiki/CONAE" class="mw-redirect" title="CONAE">CONAE</a>. the scheduled launch dates for 1A and 1B were further pushed back to October 2017 and October 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[243]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Despite its modest budget and numerous setbacks, academics and the sciences in Argentina have enjoyed an international respect since the turn of the 1900s, when <a href="/wiki/Luis_Agote" title="Luis Agote">Luis Agote</a> devised the first safe and effective means of <a href="/wiki/Blood_transfusion" title="Blood transfusion">blood transfusion</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Favaloro" title="René Favaloro">René Favaloro</a>, who was a pioneer in the improvement of the <a href="/wiki/Coronary_artery_bypass_surgery" title="Coronary artery bypass surgery">coronary artery bypass surgery</a>. Argentine scientists are still on the cutting edge in fields such as <a href="/wiki/Nanotechnology" title="Nanotechnology">nanotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Physics" title="Physics">physics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">computer sciences</a>, molecular biology, oncology, ecology and cardiology. <a href="/wiki/Juan_Maldacena" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Maldacena">Juan Maldacena</a>, an Argentine-American scientist, is a leading figure in <a href="/wiki/String_theory" title="String theory">string theory</a>. </p>
      <p>Space research has also become increasingly active in Argentina. Argentine built satellites include LUSAT-1 (1990), Víctor-1 (1996), PEHUENSAT-1 (2007),<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[244]</a></sup> and those developed by <a href="/wiki/CONAE" class="mw-redirect" title="CONAE">CONAE</a>, the Argentine space agency, of the SAC series.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[245]</a></sup> Argentina has its own satellite programme, nuclear power station designs (4th generation) and public nuclear energy company <a href="/wiki/INVAP" title="INVAP">INVAP</a>, which provides several countries with nuclear reactors.<sup id="cite_ref-science_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-science-261">[246]</a></sup> Established in 1991, the <a href="/wiki/CONAE" class="mw-redirect" title="CONAE">CONAE</a> has since launched two satellites successfully and,<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[247]</a></sup> in June 2009, secured an agreement with the <a href="/wiki/European_Space_Agency" title="European Space Agency">European Space Agency</a> for the installation of a 35-m diameter antenna and other mission support facilities at the <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Auger_Observatory" title="Pierre Auger Observatory">Pierre Auger Observatory</a>, the world's foremost <a href="/wiki/Cosmic_ray" title="Cosmic ray">cosmic ray</a> observatory.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[248]</a></sup> The facility will contribute to numerous ESA space probes, as well as CONAE's own, domestic research projects. Chosen from 20 potential sites and one of only three such ESA installations in the world, the new antenna will create a triangulation which will allow the ESA to ensure mission coverage around the clock<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[249]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Argentina" title="Tourism in Argentina">Tourism in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The country had 5.57&nbsp;million visitors in 2013, ranking in terms of the international tourist arrivals as the top destination in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, and second in <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a> after Mexico.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2014_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2014-265">[250]</a></sup> Revenues from international tourists reached <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$4.41</span> billion in 2013, down from <span style="white-space: nowrap">US$4.89</span> billion in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-UNWTO2014_265-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNWTO2014-265">[250]</a></sup> The country's capital city, <a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, is the most visited city in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[251]</a></sup> There are 30 <a href="/wiki/National_Parks_of_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="National Parks of Argentina">National Parks of Argentina</a> including many <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites in Argentina">World Heritage Sites</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:908px">
       <div class="thumbinner">
        <div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto">
         <a href="/wiki/File:2014_FOZ_003.JPG" class="image" title="The Iguazú Falls, in Misiones Province, it is one of the New7Wonders of Nature."><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2014_FOZ_003.JPG/900px-2014_FOZ_003.JPG" decoding="async" width="900" height="230" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2014_FOZ_003.JPG/1350px-2014_FOZ_003.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/2014_FOZ_003.JPG/1800px-2014_FOZ_003.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3504" data-file-height="896"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2014_FOZ_003.JPG" title="File:2014 FOZ 003.JPG"> </a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Iguaz%C3%BA_Falls" class="mw-redirect" title="Iguazú Falls">Iguazú Falls</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Misiones_Province" title="Misiones Province">Misiones Province</a>, it is one of the <a href="/wiki/New7Wonders_of_Nature" title="New7Wonders of Nature">New7Wonders of Nature</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[252]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Argentina" title="Demographics of Argentina">Demographics of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Argentines" title="Argentines">Argentines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Buildings" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg/220px-Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg/330px-Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg/440px-Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="2134"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Avenida_Callao_al_500.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture" title="Beaux-Arts architecture">Beaux Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rationalism_(architecture)" title="Rationalism (architecture)">Rationalist</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a>, and Belgian-Dutch architecture on <a href="/wiki/Callao_Avenue" class="mw-redirect" title="Callao Avenue">Callao Avenue</a>, Buenos Aires.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/INDEC" class="mw-redirect" title="INDEC">2010 census</a> counted 40,117,096 inhabitants, up from 36,260,130 in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[253]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[254]</a></sup> Argentina ranks third in South America in total population, fourth in Latin America and 33rd globally. Its population density of 15 persons per square kilometer of land area is well below the world average of 50 persons. The population growth rate in 2010 was an estimated 1.03% annually, with a birth rate of 17.7 live births per 1,000 inhabitants and a mortality rate of 7.4 deaths per 1,000 inhabitants. Since 2010, the crude <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">net migration rate</a> has ranged from below zero to up to four immigrants per 1,000 inhabitants per year.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina is in the midst of a <a href="/wiki/Demographic_transition" title="Demographic transition">demographic transition</a> to an older and slower-growing population. The proportion of people under 15 is 25.6%, a little below the world average of 28%, and the proportion of people 65 and older is relatively high at 10.8%. In Latin America this is second only to <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">Uruguay</a> and well above the world average, which is currently 7%. Argentina has one of Latin America's lowest <a href="/wiki/Population_growth_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Population growth rate">population growth rates</a> as well as a comparatively low <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rate</a>. Its birth rate of 2.3 children per woman is considerably below the high of 7.0 children born per woman in 1895,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[256]</a></sup> though still nearly twice as high as in Spain or Italy, which are culturally and demographically similar.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[258]</a></sup> The median age is 31.9 years and <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth is 77.14 years.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[259]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010, Argentina became the first country in Latin America, the second in the Americas, and the tenth worldwide to legalize same-sex marriage.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[260]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[261]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnography">Ethnography</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ethnography_of_Argentina" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnography of Argentina">Ethnography of Argentina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Argentina" title="Immigration to Argentina">Immigration to Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/220px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="276" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/330px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG/440px-XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2399" data-file-height="3006"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:XXXIV_Fiesta_Nacional_del_Inmigrante_-_desfile_-_colectividad_italiana_2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Over 25 million or 62.5% of Argentina's population have at least one <a href="/wiki/Italian_Argentines" title="Italian Argentines">Italian immigrant ancestor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LaMatanza_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LaMatanza-27">[22]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As with other areas of new settlement, such as <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_Brazil" class="mw-redirect" title="Demography of Brazil">Brazil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_the_United_States" class="mw-redirect" title="Demography of the United States">United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_Canada" class="mw-redirect" title="Demography of Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_Australia" title="Demography of Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_New_Zealand" class="mw-redirect" title="Demography of New Zealand">New Zealand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_Uruguay" class="mw-redirect" title="Demography of Uruguay">Uruguay</a>, Argentina is considered a country of immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-encuesta_277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encuesta-277">[262]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Coke_278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Coke-278">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[264]</a></sup> Argentines usually refer to the country as a <i>crisol de razas</i> (crucible of races, or <a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">melting pot</a>). </p>
      <p>In colonial times, the ethnic composition of Argentina was the result of the interaction of the pre-Columbian indigenous population with a colonizing population of Spanish origin and with sub-Saharan African slaves. Before the middle 19th century, the ethnic make up of Argentina was very similar to that of other countries of <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_America" title="Hispanic America">Hispanic America</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[265]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-structure_281-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-structure-281">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[267]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[268]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Between 1857 and 1950 Argentina was the country with the second biggest immigration wave in the world, at 6.6&nbsp;million, second only to the United States in the numbers of immigrants received (27&nbsp;million) and ahead of other areas of new settlement like Canada, Brazil and Australia.<sup id="cite_ref-ref1_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref1-284">[269]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ref2_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref2-285">[270]</a></sup> However, mass European immigration did not have the same impact in the whole country. According to the 1914 national census, 30% of Argentina's population was foreign-born, including 50% of the people in the city of Buenos Aires, but foreigners were only 2% in the provinces of <a href="/wiki/Catamarca_Province" title="Catamarca Province">Catamarca</a> and <a href="/wiki/La_Rioja_Province,_Argentina" title="La Rioja Province, Argentina">La Rioja</a> (North West region).<sup id="cite_ref-structure_281-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-structure-281">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Strikingly, at those times, the national population doubled every two decades. This belief is endured in the popular saying <i>"los argentinos descienden de los barcos"</i> (Argentines descend from the ships). Therefore, most Argentines are descended from the 19th- and 20th-century immigrants of the <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Argentina" title="Immigration to Argentina">great immigration wave to Argentina</a> (1850–1955),<sup id="cite_ref-Lizcano_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lizcano-286">[271]</a></sup> with a great majority of these immigrants coming from diverse European countries, particularly Italy and Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-ref1_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ref1-284">[269]</a></sup> The majority of Argentines descend from multiple European ethnic groups, primarily of <a href="/wiki/Italian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Italian people">Italian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Spanish_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish people">Spanish</a> descent, with over 25&nbsp;million Argentines (almost 60% of the population) having some partial Italian origins.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[272]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentina is home to a significant <a href="/wiki/Arab_Argentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Argentine">Arab</a> population; including those with partial descent, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Argentines" title="Arab Argentines">Arab Argentines</a> number 1.3 to 3.5&nbsp;million, mostly of <a href="/wiki/Syrian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian people">Syrian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese</a> origin. As in the United States, they are considered <a href="/wiki/White_people" title="White people">white</a>. The majority of Arab Argentines are <a href="/wiki/Christians" title="Christians">Christians</a> belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Maronite_Church" title="Maronite Church">Maronite Church</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic Church">Roman Catholic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Orthodox Churches">Eastern Orthodox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Rite_Catholic_Churches" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Rite Catholic Churches">Eastern Rite Catholic Churches</a>. A minority are <a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a>, albeit the largest Muslim community in the Americas. The <a href="/wiki/Asian_Argentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Asian Argentine">Asian</a> population in the country numbers around 180,000 individuals, most of whom are of <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people" title="Chinese people">Chinese</a><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[273]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Korean_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Korean people">Korean</a> descent, although an older <a href="/wiki/Japanese_people" title="Japanese people">Japanese</a> community originating from the early 20th century still exists.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[274]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A 2010 study conducted on 218 individuals by the Argentine geneticist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daniel_Corach&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daniel Corach (page does not exist)">Daniel Corach</a> established that the genetic map of Argentina is composed of 79% from different European ethnicities (mainly Italian and Spanish), 18% of different indigenous ethnicities, and 4.3% of African ethnic groups; 63.6% of the tested group had at least one ancestor who was <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Argentina" title="Indigenous peoples in Argentina">Indigenous</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-onlinelibrary.wiley.com_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-onlinelibrary.wiley.com-290">[275]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[276]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>From the 1970s, immigration has mostly been coming from <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">Paraguay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>, with smaller numbers from the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, Ecuador and <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[277]</a></sup> The Argentine government estimates that 750,000 inhabitants lack official documents and has launched a program<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[278]</a></sup> to encourage illegal immigrants to declare their status in return for two-year residence visas—so far over 670,000 applications have been processed under the program.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetics_studies">Genetics studies</span></h3> 
      <ul>
       <li>Homburguer et al., 2015, <a href="/wiki/PLOS_One" title="PLOS One">PLOS One</a> Genetics: 67% European, 28% Amerindian, 4% African and 1,4% Asian.<sup id="cite_ref-Genomic_Insights_into_the_Ancestry_and_Demographic_History_of_South_America_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Genomic_Insights_into_the_Ancestry_and_Demographic_History_of_South_America-295">[280]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>Avena et al., 2012, <a href="/wiki/PLOS_One" title="PLOS One">PLOS One</a> Genetics: 65% European, 31% Amerindian, and 4% African.<sup id="cite_ref-Heterogeneity_in_Genetic_Admixture_across_Different_Regions_of_Argentina_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heterogeneity_in_Genetic_Admixture_across_Different_Regions_of_Argentina-296">[281]</a></sup> 
        <ul>
         <li>Buenos Aires Province: 76% European and 24% others.</li> 
         <li>South Zone (Chubut Province): 54% European and 46% others.</li> 
         <li>Northeast Zone (Misiones, Corrientes, Chaco &amp; Formosa provinces): 54% European and 46% others.</li> 
         <li>Northwest Zone (Salta Province): 33% European and 67% others.</li>
        </ul></li> 
       <li>Oliveira, 2008, on <a href="/wiki/Universidade_de_Bras%C3%ADlia" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidade de Brasília">Universidade de Brasília</a>: 60% European, 31% Amerindian and 9% African.<sup id="cite_ref-Oliveira,_2008_297-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oliveira,_2008-297">[282]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_Society" title="National Geographic Society">National Geographic</a>: 52% European, 27% Amerindian ancestry, 9% African and 9% others.<sup id="cite_ref-Reference_Populations:_Geno_2.0_Next_Generation_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reference_Populations:_Geno_2.0_Next_Generation-298">[283]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Argentina" title="Languages of Argentina">Languages of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg/220px-Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="383" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg/330px-Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg/440px-Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="908" data-file-height="1581"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dialectos_del_espa%C3%B1ol_en_Argentina.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Dialectal variants of the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish language</a> in Argentina
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <i><a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[M]</a></sup> official language is <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish</a>, spoken by almost all Argentines.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup> The country is the largest <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">Spanish-speaking society</a> that universally employs <i><a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">voseo</a></i>, the use of the <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">pronoun</a> <i>vos</i> instead of <i>tú</i> ("you"), which imposes the use of alternative verb forms as well. Due to the extensive Argentine geography, Spanish has a strong variation among regions, although the prevalent dialect is <i><a href="/wiki/Rioplatense_Spanish" title="Rioplatense Spanish">Rioplatense</a></i>, primarily spoken in the La Plata Basin and accented similarly to the <a href="/wiki/Neapolitan_language" title="Neapolitan language">Neapolitan language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEColantoniGurlekian2004107–119_301-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEColantoniGurlekian2004107–119-301">[285]</a></sup> Italian and other European immigrants influenced <i><a href="/wiki/Lunfardo" title="Lunfardo">Lunfardo</a></i>—the regional slang—permeating the vernacular vocabulary of other Latin American countries as well. </p>
      <p>There are several second-languages in widespread use among the Argentine population: </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>English,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[N]</a></sup> taught since <a href="/wiki/Elementary_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Elementary school">elementary school</a>. 42.3% of Argentines claim to speak it, with 15.4% of them claiming to have a high level of language comprehension.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a>, by 1.5&nbsp;million people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[O]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>, specially its <a href="/wiki/Levantine_Arabic" title="Levantine Arabic">Northern Levantine dialect</a>, by one million people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Standard_German" title="Standard German">Standard German</a>, by 400,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[P]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Yiddish_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Yiddish language">Yiddish</a>, by 200,000 people,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Argentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish Argentine">largest Jewish population</a> in Latin America and 7th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201325–26,_49–50_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201325–26,_49–50-305">[286]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">Guaraní</a>, by 200,000 people,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup> mostly in Corrientes (where it is official <i>de jure</i>) and Misiones.<sup id="cite_ref-Corrientes-5598_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Corrientes-5598-4">[3]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">Catalan</a>, by 174,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Quechua_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Quechua language">Quechua</a>, by 65,000 people, mostly in the Northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Wich%C3%AD_languages" title="Wichí languages">Wichí</a>, by 53,700 people, mainly in Chaco<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup> where, along with <a href="/wiki/Kom_language_(South_America)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kom language (South America)">Kom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Moqoit_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Moqoit language">Moqoit</a>, it is official <i>de jure</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-kom_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kom-6">[5]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Vlax_Romani_language" title="Vlax Romani language">Vlax Romani</a>, by 52,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_South_America" title="Albanians in South America">40,000 people</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[287]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Japanese_language" title="Japanese language">Japanese</a>, by 32,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Aymara_language" title="Aymara language">Aymara</a>, by 30,000 people, mostly in the Northwest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>, by 27,000 people.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>, 5,000 people in Patagonia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014_300-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELewisSimonsFennig2014-300">[284]</a></sup> Some districts have incorporated it as an educational language.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips2000602_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAeberhardBensonPhillips2000602-307">[288]</a></sup></li>
      </ul> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Argentina" title="Religion in Argentina">Religion in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Francis_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/170px-Francis_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="255" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/255px-Francis_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Francis_2013.jpg/340px-Francis_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="928" data-file-height="1392"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Francis_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Francis</a>, the first pope from the New World, was born and raised in Argentina.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Constitution guarantees <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_religion" title="Freedom of religion">freedom of religion</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._14,_20_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaarts._14,_20-308">[289]</a></sup> Although it enforces neither an official nor a state faith,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFayt1985347Bidart_Campos200553_309-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFayt1985347Bidart_Campos200553-309">[290]</a></sup> it gives <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a> a preferential status.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._2_310-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConstitution_of_Argentinaart._2-310">[291]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[Q]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to a 2008 CONICET poll, Argentines were 76.5% <a href="/wiki/Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholic">Catholic</a>, 11.3% <a href="/wiki/Agnostic" class="mw-redirect" title="Agnostic">Agnostics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atheist" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheist">Atheists</a>, 9% <a href="/wiki/Evangelicalism" title="Evangelicalism">Evangelical Protestants</a>, 1.2% <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah's Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>, and 0.9% <a href="/wiki/Mormon" class="mw-redirect" title="Mormon">Mormons</a>, while 1.2% followed other religions, including <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal20089_313-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal20089-313">[293]</a></sup> These figures appear to have changed quite significantly in recent years: data recorded in 2017 indicated that Catholics made up 66% of the population, indicating a drop of 10.5% in nine years, and the nonreligious in the country standing at 21% of the population, indicating an almost doubling over the same period.<sup id="cite_ref-Latinobarometro_2017_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Latinobarometro_2017-314">[294]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country is home to both the <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Argentina" title="Islam in Argentina">largest Muslim</a><sup id="cite_ref-irfr1_311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irfr1-311">[292]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Argentine" class="mw-redirect" title="Jewish Argentine">largest Jewish</a> communities in Latin America, the latter being the seventh most populous in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201350_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDellaPergola201350-315">[295]</a></sup> Argentina is a member of the <a href="/wiki/International_Holocaust_Remembrance_Alliance" title="International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance">International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-irfr1_311-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-irfr1-311">[292]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Argentines show high individualization and de-institutionalization of religious beliefs;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200821_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200821-316">[296]</a></sup> 23.8% claim to always attend religious services; 49.1% seldom do and 26.8% never do.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200824_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMallimaciEsquivelIrrazábal200824-317">[297]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 13 March 2013, Argentine <a href="/wiki/Pope_Francis" title="Pope Francis">Jorge Mario Bergoglio</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cardinal_(Catholicism)" class="mw-redirect" title="Cardinal (Catholicism)">Cardinal</a> <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Buenos_Aires" title="Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Buenos Aires">Archbishop of Buenos Aires</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave,_2013" class="mw-redirect" title="Papal conclave, 2013">elected</a> <a href="/wiki/Pope" title="Pope">Bishop of Rome</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Pontiff" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Pontiff">Supreme Pontiff</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>. He took the name "<a href="/wiki/St._Francis_of_Assisi" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Francis of Assisi">Francis</a>", and he became the first Pope from either the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> or from the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere" title="Southern Hemisphere">Southern Hemisphere</a>; he is the first Pope born outside of Europe since the <a href="/wiki/Papal_conclave" title="Papal conclave">election</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pope_Gregory_III" title="Pope Gregory III">Pope Gregory III</a> (who was <a href="/wiki/Syrian" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian">Syrian</a>) in 741.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[298]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Argentina_by_population" title="List of cities in Argentina by population">List of cities in Argentina by population</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Argentina is highly urbanized, with 92% of its population living in cities:<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[299]</a></sup> the ten largest metropolitan areas account for half of the population. About 3&nbsp;million people live in the city of Buenos Aires, and including the Greater Buenos Aires metropolitan area it totals around 13&nbsp;million, making it one of the largest urban areas in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-majorcities_320-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-320">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The metropolitan areas of Córdoba and Rosario have around 1.3&nbsp;million inhabitants each.<sup id="cite_ref-majorcities_320-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-320">[300]</a></sup> Mendoza, San Miguel de Tucumán, La Plata, Mar del Plata, Salta and Santa Fe have at least half a million people each.<sup id="cite_ref-majorcities_320-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-majorcities-320">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The population is unequally distributed: about 60% live in the Pampas region (21% of the total area), including 15&nbsp;million people in Buenos Aires province. The provinces of Córdoba and Santa Fe, and the city of Buenos Aires have 3&nbsp;million each. Seven other provinces have over one million people each: Mendoza, Tucumán, Entre Ríos, Salta, Chaco, Corrientes and Misiones. With 64.3 inhabitants per square kilometre (167/sq&nbsp;mi), Tucumán is the only Argentine province more densely populated than the world average; by contrast, the southern province of Santa Cruz has around 1.1/km<sup>2</sup> (2.8/sq&nbsp;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[301]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">5</td>

        <tr> 
         <td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">6</td>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Argentina" title="Education in Argentina">Education in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg/330px-World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg/495px-World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg/660px-World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="940" data-file-height="415"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:World_map_of_countries_by_literacy_rate.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Argentina has historically been placed high in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_literacy_rate" title="List of countries by literacy rate">global rankings of literacy</a>, with rates similar to those of developed countries.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Argentine education system consists of four levels:<sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[303]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>An initial level for children between 45 days to 5 years old, with the last two years<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[304]</a></sup> being compulsory.</li> 
       <li>An elementary or <a href="/wiki/Lower_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Lower school">lower school</a> mandatory level lasting 6 or 7 years.<sup id="cite_ref-leveldiff_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leveldiff-325">[R]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Literacy_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Literacy rate">literacy rate</a> was 98.07%.<sup id="cite_ref-educ1_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-educ1-326">[305]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>A secondary or <a href="/wiki/High_school" class="mw-redirect" title="High school">high school</a> mandatory level lasting 5 or 6 years.<sup id="cite_ref-leveldiff_325-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-leveldiff-325">[R]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 38.5% of people over age 20 had completed secondary school.<sup id="cite_ref-educ2_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-educ2-327">[306]</a></sup></li> 
       <li>A <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher level</a>, divided in tertiary, university and post-graduate sub-levels. in 2013<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> there were 47 <a href="/wiki/List_of_Argentine_universities" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Argentine universities">national public universities</a> across the country, as well as 46 private ones.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[307]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Argentina&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> 7.1% of people over age 20 had graduated from university.<sup id="cite_ref-educ2_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-educ2-327">[306]</a></sup> The public universities of <a href="/wiki/University_of_Buenos_Aires" title="University of Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_C%C3%B3rdoba" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad Nacional de Córdoba">Córdoba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_La_Plata" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad Nacional de La Plata">La Plata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Universidad_Nacional_de_Rosario" class="mw-redirect" title="Universidad Nacional de Rosario">Rosario</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/National_Technological_University" title="National Technological University">National Technological University</a> are some of the most important.</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>The Argentine state guarantees universal, secular and free-of-charge public education for all levels.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[S]</a></sup> Responsibility for educational supervision is organized at the federal and individual provincial states. In the last decades the role of the private sector has grown across all educational stages. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_care">Health care</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Argentina" title="Health care in Argentina">Health care in Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/220px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/330px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg/440px-Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2848" data-file-height="2134"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Plaza_Houssay_Av_C%C3%B3rdoba_Facultad_Medicina.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The University of Buenos Aires School of Medicine, alma mater to many of the country's 3,000 medical graduates, annually<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[308]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Health care is provided through a combination of employer and labour union-sponsored plans (<i>Obras Sociales</i>), government insurance plans, public hospitals and clinics and through private health insurance plans. Health care cooperatives number over 300 (of which 200 are related to <a href="/wiki/Trade_union" title="Trade union">labour unions</a>) and provide health care for half the population; the national INSSJP (popularly known as PAMI) covers nearly all of the five million senior citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-iadb_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iadb-331">[309]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are more than 153,000 hospital beds, 121,000 physicians and 37,000 dentists (ratios comparable to <a href="/wiki/Developed_country" title="Developed country">developed nations</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-deis_332-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deis-332">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-undata_333-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-undata-333">[311]</a></sup> The relatively high access to medical care has historically resulted in mortality patterns and trends similar to developed nations': from 1953 to 2005, deaths from <a href="/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease" title="Cardiovascular disease">cardiovascular disease</a> increased from 20% to 23% of the total, those from <a href="/wiki/Tumors" class="mw-redirect" title="Tumors">tumors</a> from 14% to 20%, <a href="/wiki/Respiratory" class="mw-redirect" title="Respiratory">respiratory</a> problems from 7% to 14%, <a href="/wiki/Digestive_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Digestive system">digestive</a> maladies (non-infectious) from 7% to 11%, strokes a steady 7%, injuries, 6%, and <a href="/wiki/Infection" title="Infection">infectious</a> diseases, 4%. Causes related to <a href="/wiki/Senility" class="mw-redirect" title="Senility">senility</a> led to many of the rest. Infant deaths have fallen from 19% of all deaths in 1953 to 3% in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-deis_332-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deis-332">[310]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-un57_334-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-un57-334">[312]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The availability of health care has also reduced <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">infant mortality</a> from 70 per 1000 live births in 1948<sup id="cite_ref-un97_335-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-un97-335">[313]</a></sup> to 12.1 in 2009<sup id="cite_ref-deis_332-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-deis-332">[310]</a></sup> and raised <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> at birth from 60 years to 76.<sup id="cite_ref-un97_335-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-un97-335">[313]</a></sup> Though these figures compare favorably with global averages, they fall short of levels in developed nations and in 2006, Argentina ranked fourth in Latin America.<sup id="cite_ref-undata_333-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-undata-333">[311]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Argentina" title="Culture of Argentina">Culture of Argentina</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Argentines" title="List of Argentines">List of Argentines</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
